message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms, including pain, stiffness, and difficulty with movement, suggest rotator cuff tear. The drop arm test, which involves elevating the arm and then lowering it slowly, is a useful test for diagnosing rotator cuff tear. Injection of lidocaine into the subacromial space did not relieve the pain, indicating that the pain is not due to subacromial bursitis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms suggest rotator cuff tear, as there is pain with movement, loss of function, and weakness on passive abduction. Injection of lidocaine into the subacromial space did not relieve the pain, ruling out subacromial bursitis. Cervical radiculopathy and biceps tendinitis typically present with different symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has pain in the top of her shoulder that is worse with movement, stiffness in the morning, and difficulty with activities like brushing her hair and playing tennis, which are all indicative of rotator cuff tear. The pain between 60 and 120 degrees of abduction and inability to hold her arm up suggest rotator cuff dysfunction. The lidocaine injection not relieving pain or improving active range of motion confirms the diagnosis. Cervical radiculopathy can cause similar symptoms but the lidocaine injection would have relieved pain if that was the diagnosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest a rotator cuff tear, such as pain at the top of the shoulder and difficulty with overhead activities. The pain between 60 and 120 degrees of abduction and inability to hold her arm up during passive range of motion support this diagnosis. Injection of lidocaine into the subacromial space did not relieve the pain or improve range of motion, also supporting a rotator cuff tear over subacromial bursitis. Cervical radiculopathy and biceps tendinitis are less likely based on the patient's history and physical examination findings.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient has pain and stiffness in the shoulder with decreased range of motion and weakness that suggests rotator cuff tear. The lidocaine injection did not relieve the pain or improve the range of motion, which is also consistent with rotator cuff tear. The other options have different symptoms and physical examination findings.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest rotator cuff tear. The pain is localized to the top of the shoulder and worsens with movement, there is stiffness in the morning, and there is weakness raising the arm from 90 degrees of abduction. Injection of lidocaine into the subacromial space did not help, ruling out subacromial bursitis. Cervical radiculopathy and biceps tendinitis present differently with different symptoms.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient's symptoms suggest a rotator cuff tear, as there is pain with movement and inability to hold her arm up when lowered slowly. Injection of 1% lidocaine into the subacromial space did not relieve the pain or improve active range of motion, which supports the diagnosis of rotator cuff tear. Cervical radiculopathy would cause pain and numbness that radiates down the arm, which is not described in this case. Subacromial bursitis and biceps tendinitis would not account for the inability to hold the arm up when lowered slowly.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The main symptoms are pain in the top of the shoulder and difficulty with abduction of the arm. The inability to hold up the arm and dropping it to the side are signs of a rotator cuff tear, which is the most likely diagnosis. The lidocaine injection not relieving the pain also supports this diagnosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms, including pain with abduction and difficulty holding the arm up, suggest a rotator cuff tear. Subacromial bursitis may cause similar symptoms but lidocaine injection would typically provide some relief, which was not the case here. Cervical radiculopathy and biceps tendinitis have different patterns of pain and weakness.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms suggest a rotator cuff tear. Passive range of motion is normal, ruling out subacromial bursitis and biceps tendinitis. Lidocaine injection did not relieve the pain or improve active range of motion, further supporting a diagnosis of rotator cuff tear. Cervical radiculopathy is less likely given the localized pain to the top of the shoulder.
